title: AB 933
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature enacted the FAST Act to provide funding certainty for surface transportation and grant programs for impaired driving interventions, including 24/7 Sobriety programs. California aims to establish a statewide 24/7 Sobriety program to qualify for FAST Act grant funding and additional NHTSA funding. The Legislature enacted the FAST Act to provide funding for impaired driving interventions, including 24/7 Sobriety programs. California aims to establish a statewide 24/7 Sobriety program to qualify for FAST Act grant funding and additional NHTSA funding. The court may order individuals convicted of DUI to enroll in a 24/7 Sobriety program as a condition of probation if they have prior DUI convictions within 10 years. The court may require individuals arrested for DUI to enroll in a 24/7 Sobriety program as a condition of release on bond if they have prior DUI convictions within 10 years. A person with a suspended or revoked driving privilege can enroll in a 24/7 Sobriety program to obtain a restricted driving privilege if they have committed a violation within 10 years of a previous DUI conviction. Participation in the program may be required for a minimum of one year. A person with a suspended or revoked driving privilege can enroll in a 24/7 Sobriety program for a minimum of one year. The program requires abstaining from alcohol or controlled substances, with breath testing at least twice daily or through a monitoring device. Program violations result in immediate but modest sanctions, and the methodology must be evidence-based. Evaluation research shows that the 24/7 Sobriety program produces positive results attributed to the program itself, peer-reviewed by experts, and endorsed by federal agencies. Testing methods for violations should be timely and effective. The court prioritizes testing methods for violations close in time to the occurrence. Program costs are based on ability to pay. Programs are limited to 180 days unless positive for alcohol or drugs. The court imposes a program of up to 180 days unless the defendant tests positive for alcohol or drugs. The Office of Traffic Safety includes provisions for the 24/7 Sobriety program in its highway safety plan. The department establishes uniform data collection on participant information, testing, fees, and payments. Section 1808 of the Vehicle Code allows public inspection of department records related to vehicle registration, driver's license applications, convictions, and accident reports, except in cases where confidentiality is required by law. The department in Sacramento provides abstracts of convictions and accident reports based on the date of occurrence: 10 years for certain violations, 7 years for two-point violations, and 3 years for accidents and other violations. The department in Sacramento provides abstracts of convictions and accident reports based on the date of occurrence: 10 years for certain violations, 7 years for two-point violations, and 3 years for accidents and other violations. The department discloses suspensions and revocations of driving privileges for three years following termination of the action or reinstatement, except for specific cases where disclosure is limited to the actual suspension period. Judicially set aside or stayed suspensions or revocations are not disclosed. The department in Sacramento provides abstracts of convictions and accident reports based on the date of occurrence for specific time periods. Suspensions and revocations are disclosed for three years following termination or reinstatement, except for cases that are judicially set aside or stayed. Personal information is only disclosed in compliance with the Driver’s Privacy Protection Act of 1994. Convictions of certain offenses are disclosed to courts and law enforcement agencies for 10 years for penalty enforcement purposes. The department in Sacramento provides abstracts of convictions and accident reports based on specific time periods. Convictions of Section 191.5 or subdivision (a) of Section 192.5 of the Penal Code punished as a felony are disclosed for penalty enforcement purposes. Consent to use a driver's license number for insurance or employment purposes is presumed if provided to an insurer, employer, or prospective employer. The insurance agent or broker can transmit motor vehicle records for specific purposes and is not responsible for how the recipient handles the records. Prior to transmitting records to an insurer without a written agreement, the broker must obtain an agreement to handle the records according to state and federal laws.
